description:
This session is aimed at creatively engaging children to use a variety of talents towards a common goal.  Children will add to an activity course for the Sphero or Arduino robot, to create a colourful, interactive end result by the end of the weekend.
Example:
A child (or adult) might decide to make a tunnel or see-saw bridge etc... to add to the course then attach a MakeyMakey or Arduino and program it using Scratch, S4A or Mind+ etc... to code a response to an input for example a noise of some sort or traffic lights to change at another section.
The aim is to demonstrate how many skills come together to create a great end result and to realise how all skills are valuable.  i.e. a child may choose to create and decorate a tunnel without any coding.
Skills:
Art, design, craft, coding, electronics, collaboration etc...
title: Run the Gauntlet

description: "Music is a moral law. It gives soul to the universe, wings to the mind, flight to the imagination, and charm and gaiety to life and to everything.Where words fail, music speaks. " this quote impacts me to propose a session .Most of us like Music . Keeping the point of view and to attract participants for Mozfest i prepared a plan to MozJukebox- its a place where participants can dedicate their special songs to their beloved ones and this session makes different from others and as well as participant's will learn how open web and music related to each other and by the way the can perform their own activity . we are here to make them aware of this.
title: Juke Mozilla
Digital Identities: the landscape, the future, and legal hacking

description:
The session is built upon the idea of turning ordinary objects into connected web aware devices. The participants of this workshop will learn how the Web of Things might be used to provide a standardised approach for connecting objects to the web.
The participants will choose an object and then apply 'Web of Things' thinking to make the object become a Web Thing (WT).
A Web Thing (WT) is an intelligent sensor (or sensor array) that can recognise an event, understand its own state and take action depending on the input.
Through active participation the people can learn about the Web of Things in new and fun ways.
title: Intelligent Web Things

description: Appmaker and Webmaker currently require an Internet connection to work. On this session I will present the "Appmaker in a box" that allows the facilitator to create a self contained Appmaker workshop without the need for an internet connection. This is needed to teach on more poor or remote locations where internet access is not ubiquitous.
title: Appmaker in a Box

description:
Democracy Street is an interactive digital arts and learning project, developed and curated by the artist Jon Adams. Commissioned by the Houses of Parliament and Arts Council England, and created in collaboration with Mozilla and Si digital, Democracy Street aims to raise awareness of the power of democracy and the importance of free and open information.
We do this by engaging the public in the generation of a Digital Interactive Map that gives insight into the people and events that shaped our political landscape since the sealing of Magna Carta.
We have created a mobile web app and website for users to discover the history of the people behind the names of their local streets - and how they contributed to democracy.
During the session participants can engage with the project directly via smartphones and mobile devices, seeing their discoveries adding data to the Interactive Map in real-time.
title: Democracy Street - Gamifying and Learning from Open Data

description: During our sessions we'll talk about the importance of work in our lives, how to discover what you're good at, where to find the people who are like you, and how to find your way in an increasingly fragmented and entrepreneurial culture of work where strict job titles and roles are becoming increasingly irrelevant.
title: We're living in the future of work

description: The Session is about to teaching and localizing stuff. The web is growing day by day with awesome learners and we need to make it possible to provide in all possible languages, The Webmaker is available in many languages possible but its also requiring to localize the web into different modes where participation or people can reach out to the web. This session is all about the teach and do the productivity content localization with purity of content localization. Its a session to make the things with locale languages and localizing the things. So the engagement of people or participation can reach more with their locale languages.
title: Localize The Web

description:
Womoz is Mozilla program that encourages women to contribute to the open web under Mozilla's mission of openness, innovation & opportunity. Women can also feel encouraged to participate in a number of Mozilla projects such as Firefox OS, webmaker among others.
Therefore this session will introduce women to a functional area called WOMOZ, that sensitises women on how to easily make good use of their skiils on the web depending on what they frequently use the it for.
title: WOMOZ - Women in Mozilla.
Design Thinking for Participation
Coderdojo and Open Badges

description: Understanding how memes convey opinions and how their spread relates to the spread of rhetorics behind those opinions but also to the spread of fake information, and intox in general is the overall goal of the session. We follow the way politically-charged information spreads online and can go viral. To this end, we track the spread of memes online using image search platforms, network reconstruction and mapping the changes in their rhetoric across their lifetime.
title: "How does information spreads online? Memes explain"

description: My session will be based on ‘Webmaker for Android’ and the main target would be women (especially young ones). However, guys can join as well. People will be able to know about the WoMoz program and Mozilla while creating contents about them. They will be given some specific topics to create content which will be related to Mozilla, open web and online privacy. My main goals are: people will learn about open web, online privacy, Mozilla and the WoMoz program while using the application. They will surf on the internet about the topics and know in more efficient way. From web users they will become web makers. Since young people learn fast it will be great opportunity to work with them.
title: Webmaker and WoMoz

description: This session will be centered around video content on the web. It will focus generally around mozilla/popcorn-editor which is a modular javascript library which allows users to implement the editor from popcorn.webmaker.org. While this session is primarily discussion based I will also go over a simple tutorial of implementing the editor on a website and then dive into creating additional plugins into the editor. For instance, for the demo we will go over implementing an index plugin which allows users to associate specific keywords with events in the video and then store this data in the project metadata.
title: Collaboritive Video Editing on The Web

description:
Learn a little bit of HTML and CSS, whilst saving kittens in the process. In Erase All Kittens (https://eraseallkittens.com/), players must explore a fantasy Internet universe, using code to change the world around them, in order to defeat the evil Operation E.A.K. - Erase All Kittens.
E.A.K. is aimed at anyone aged 7+, but kids much younger than that have enjoyed learning with E.A.K. too.
title: E.A.K. Walk-In - Save Kittens, Learn HTML!

description:
The goal of this session is to explore how the maker-centric learning environment itself can be used as a tool for creating more opportunities to teach others. By harnessing the potential of our community, we can increase access to opportunities for making and sharing.
How can we, as educators or parents, inspire kids (and other adults!) to make with us, and empower them to take their new knowledge and skills to share with their family, friends or classmates?
What levels of engagement and understanding are required to make us feel as though we are able to take what we have learned and show it to someone else? How can we design workshops that empower participants to do that?
With these goals in mind, we will learn how to make a small project, and then share our new knowledge and skills by teaching another group how to make it too.
title: Making Together

description:
This session focuses on building Web Security Awareness for the attendees. Its helps  the attendees to build  their applications more securely using Web Security Tools[1].
With the help of security tools, People can attack their own designed Web applications and check for the vulnerabilities in their applications and code it more securely.
For an instance, Assume a coder created Login page, He can use ZAP (Web Security Tool) to attack his Login page in different ways and sort out the ways to trace out the flaws. In this way ZAP gives the coder chance to build their Web Application more securely. (Though its only one of the many features of ZAP).
title: Securing the Web

description:
Reporting the news involves gathering, assessing, creating and presenting information... often in an unstructured manner, whether for print, digital or broadcast. The relationships between the people, events and themes in the coverage get lost in a sea of text or video, as does the opportunity to leverage this knowledge and data in future reporting.
This session will explore methods of retaining the structured data that lives in your notes (or thoughts) as you develop a story.
title: Reporting with Structured Data

description:
Our session will allow the attendees come up with webmaker makes using the webmaker app, they will learn how to teach the Internet to others with both the availability and unavailability of Internet connectivity, and they will also leave with a proper understanding of the web, and learn how to use the web reliably and efficiently, which will enable them become citizens of the web
Goal: Teach the open web offline and translate this knowledge to the web by illustrating the enhanced usage of the web.
Participants will learn how to train the open web without Internet connectivity and acquire skills of interacting with the web reliably and efficiently.
Participants will learn, create makes, play games and compete in challenges
title: Enhancing Open Web Experience

description:
1. To provide a comprehensive view of the iHub ecosystem and how balance is maintained
2. To showcase how iHub has evolved towards sustainability
3. To highlight ever-present sustainability challenges iHub faces
4. To openly brainstorm with the audience on how to overcome challenges
title: Sustaining an Innovation Hub: Lessons from the iHub

description:
Understanding privacy is very important. Many adults think that they have lost control over their personal information , which is used by the online companies. This session will help them put their data in control. Mozilla has implemented a number of privacy features in their products and this session will promote those features.
Privacy Security booths can have series of booths:
1) Password Booth (How to make your password strong)
2) Tracking Booth (See how websites track you)
3) Firefox Features Booth (How Firefox can help you)
Eg: Lightbeam,Private Browsing,Forget Button,etc
4) Firefox + DuckDuckGo Booth
(demonstrate why Firefox with DuckDuckGo is a better choice)
5) Firefox for Phones Booth
6) Firefox OS (The only Mobile OS to have DO NOT TRACK feature)
7) Installation Booth (help attendees install privacy products on their personal laptops and phones )
8) Net Neutrality Booth (Spread awareness about)
*Differential pricing
*Surveillance
*Zero platforms
title: Privacy and Security booths at Makerparties

description: Inspired by the Things Network in Amsterdam, this session looks at crowd sourcing a free, open and distributed Internet of Things infrastructure for the benefit of everyone. The session looks at how using off the shelf Long Range Wide Area Network (LoRaWAN) components we can build city-wide IoT infrastructure that is community owned.
title: IoT is too important for big IT

description: People will learn how to use JavaScript for IoT projects with this incredibly small board. They will learn the basics of the components, how to make it run, modify and learn something new. It's all about imagination.
title: Espruino Pico and IoT
Community Co-Creation Pathways

description:
The Webmaker app for Android is great for people who do not want to write code to create a project. However this also results in a backlash from coding-minded users who want to utilize their coding capabilities to create projects.
By using the Thimble app for Android, those coding-minded users will be able to add HTML, CSS, JavaScript code to create their makes, projects, website, etc.
title: Thimble for Android

description: The session is precisely about connecting to the web, keeping self-privacy and get to know how people are using it in daily life. The understanding of inter-relation among HTTP, Browser and web documents will make the attendee to capture what the content in the INTERNET is and why it is for. From this attendee will be able to categorize the private and safety information that needs to hide from public access. The session will include a hands-on network topology build-up for mail-server(using network-simulator) and help them learn about the data packet passing more visually.  A little understanding with visual talk on data filtering will be added to let them understand about behavioral data. There will also be a little talk on net neutrality and user's right to get the web information on an equal platform. From Internet activity to Net Neutrality will be the flow of awareness talk.
title: Internet and Web Privacy- Web Literacy 101
Democracy Street

description:
It will allow users to create custom Web content easily and quickly, no coding required. Its practical, fun, and a key building block for teaching and improving Web literacy. It’s also a tool for empowering individuals and strengthening the open Web.
Goals:-
> Make active users of web!
> Allow users to create using their imagination.
> Increase interest in users for making the web!

description: In the session I aim to get participants using Scratch (a fun interactive block based programming language) with Scratch extensions both created by myself and others. These extensions allow you to do many different things with Scratch but in the session we will focus on connecting Scratch to the outside world using hardware such as as Arduinos or mobile phones and the open source extensions I have developed. If there is time we will also look at several other different Scratch extensions that others have produced that I've found interesting and also briefly detail how participants can make their own extensions.
title: Connecting everything but the kitchen sink to Scratch

description:
The idea of this panel is to share experiences on the creation and sustainability of innovation and community-run spaces like hackerspaces, makerspaces and fablabs, with a special focus on the 3rd world and its specific challenges.
In other words, that means that every participant will be able to learn from others and share their own experiences about innovation/hacking/making community-run spaces from their own perspectives.
A consequence of this is building stronger connections betwwen communities and spaces in the underdeveloped and developing world.
pathways: Global Innovation Network, Global Village Garage
title: From Garoa Hacker Clube to Olabi: 5 years of hackerspaces, makerspaces, hardware startups and creative hubs in Brazil

description: It can be a little overwhelming to receive an email asking you to give a talk, run a training session, or co-organize a hackathon if you’ve never done it before.  Fellows who collaborate with Mozilla across science, journalism, learning and advocacy need resources to assist them to effectively engage the public in a variety of situations.  This open hack sessions aims to create a space at MozFest to compile and co-create resources to assist Mozilla fellows, as well as other leaders, to engage the public.
title: Hacking on Public Engagement Resources for Fellows

description: Just like artists gain greater control over their works through self-publishing, our session will teach participants how to self-publish on the web. We will do this by teaching them to host their own web content and applications, in this case, WordPress, using basic operations skills, alongside the importance of security for privacy.
title: Self-publishing on the web - how to host your own website

description:
From cave walls to Facebook walls we have always embraced visual communication With the changing media landscape, our streams, memes, and zines have exploded with imagery, ushering in a need for visual literacy skills. We are quickly moving from images as decoration and augmentation to images as sole content and communication tool. Technology has affected knowledge in such a way as to diminish the value of “raw” information and increase the value of sense-making, as well as chip away at attention spans, sparking a need for distillation of complex ideas. Images can essentialize the cumbersome in beautiful ways. They have a “stickiness” for the viewer and challenge the critical thinking of the creator.
This hands-on session offer participants an opportunity to tinker and play with:
metaphorical thinking, iconography, pictograms, emoji, typography, sketchnotes and photography.
We’ll experiment with ways to use visual language for critical thinking, social interaction and creative expression
title: Image is Everything: Visual Thinking

pathways: New Technologies for Participation -- Challenge, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted, [Pathway] Storytellers & coders united: together we can change the world!
title: Change the world through code: how to meet the person you need in your team to do so
Charting Achievement: Using Open Badges to Design Learning Playlists

description:
The purpose of this session is to challenge current thinking about the role of African tech hubs in society by sharing insights from research on hubs as creative spaces—institutions that engage in complex problem solving. There are at least 90 African tech hubs that serve as infrastructure to catalyze technology, entrepreneurship, and innovation. Not only do they act as physical infrastructure, providing access to power, internet, and space, but they also offer access to human, financial and social capital. By distributing these resources more efficiently, hubs make it easier to build start-ups, develop tech, and foster innovation.
But can hubs also create better solutions to complex social problems? Many tech hubs are engaged in developing tech solutions for education, health, and governance challenges. However, there is an opportunity to push past “there's an app for that” thinking and reconceive tech hubs as creative spaces that foster tech-enabled, innovative problem solving.
title: Tech Hubs 2.0: What is a Tech Hub's Role in Society?

description:
Idea of workshop is to present concrete examples (from technology, medicine...) where harm is done to the end user in the name of Intellectual property. Also, libertarian view on that matter will be presented and similarities with open source and free software movement.
All of the participants will have opportunity to present their examples or discuss similar related matters that bothers them throughout workshop.
Goal of the workshop is to build blog where all the reports can be presented and where people can ask for advice on matter of IP or dubious regulations in their countries. All of that is affecting free and open Internet and individual liberties.
title: Corporatism and Intellectual property: where private ends and rent begins

description:
We’ll facilitate a fun, playful, interactive workshop, guiding participants through a paper-based storytelling game. Participants will collaboratively remix a new creative work from bits + pieces of media we provide, related to a fictional narrative, found scattered across many digital services + platforms.
Our goal is to explore how a holistic, digital system based on these interactions + principles might work, and to uncover its potential social + data privacy implications.
We’re also hoping these ideas inspire our participants to join our community of contributors, early adopters and testers, interested in the potential of our vision: a tool helping storytellers unlock their creativity. Please see:
https://vimeo.com/136997295 (video)
https://makeparallels.herokuapp.com (live demo)
title: Make Parallels

description: Web articles lead people on long journeys of hyperlinks and tab accumulation. This spreads the information out and can hurt your ability to see how it all connects. The session will focus on the discussion of these information networks and how they can be visualized. There will also be a group oriented activity that will have people working together to design a tool/UI that can be used to aid in this process.
title: Caught in the Web - How to understand how information you consume online fits together

description: This session is to teach people how to mine the web, especially the social networks to extract information. I believe, if people actually get down to mining and getting their hands dirty with this experience, then only will they clearly understand the negative side of it i.e the risks associated in the cyber world regarding the privacy and also the mindsets of hackers and web miners who can get private information through this. Thus they understand the importance of keeping information secure and private even on social networking sites like facebook or twitter in which people generally trust too much.
title: Mine your space

description:
This session will be geared towards working with elections data. We will focus on creative ways to show election results.
For example, sometimes the official divisions of a city needed for administrative tasks are not necessarily meaningful to the city’s population. In many cases, the city has living parts that do not fit in the limits of official administrative level divisions
We will show how we have solved this issue for the Elections in Buenos Aires and I hope that after the session the attendees will have some creative ideas on how to work with election data and apply them in the next elections they are interested in.
title: Draw your own election adventure, beyond official boundaries

description: With a Raspberry Pi, a bit of wire, and a phone, learn how to convert your Pi into an FM transmitter for your house-share of community cafe, and load it with audio content that everybody in range can edit and playlist.
title: Build your own FM radio station for $25 and control it from your phone

description:
The goal of the FlyWeb session is to promote, intrigue, and encourage feedback from attendees. We want to be able to engage users by showcasing our Fennec addon prototype and let their imagination do the rest because at the end of the day, FlyWeb has unlimited possibilities. We will also have tutorial materials and a full demo to showcase some popular use cases. We want to walk our attendees through the concept of advertising and consuming nearby services
on their phone. Lastly, we want our attendees to have the opportunity to see what we have been working on first hand and play with our prototype.
title: FlyWeb

description:
[Here’s the session in a nutshell: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/phillipadsmith/2014.phillipadsmith.com/master/files/colonize-github-100px.jpg ]
What would it take to simplify and unlock the collaborative power Github for all?
Today, Github is virtually everywhere. It’s become a part of most developers’ daily lives, and is increasingly spreading to the lives of non-developers too. From civic hackers, researchers and policymakers to educators, journalists and project managers, it seems like the whole world is “going Github.”
The problem is: Github is still surprisingly hard for most everyday users to unlock. Non-technical users hit big barriers when trying to understand what Github is all about. And even experienced users struggle to keep up with all the new features, integrations, and innovations.
The goal of this session will be to brainstorm and hack on solutions to that problem.
We’ll map out Github’s territory, ask the question “What if…?,” and explore what’s possible in this new world of open, networked, co-creation.
title: Github Gitdown: unlocking the potential of the world’s largest co-creation platform

description: As volunteer community leaders with little to no resources, how do we maximize resources in our community in order to achieve our goals?  This workshop allows community leaders (from novice to expert) to identify challenges in their communities, and apply Design Thinking process to come up with innovative solutions to maximize existing resources in order to achieve radical participation.  Participants will get a crash course on the Design Thinking problem solving process in a hands-on participatory exercise.
pathways: Leading and Building Community Through Participation, Participation Travel Stipend, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted
title: Design Thinking - Maximizing Resources in Your Community

description: Our session will focus on the idea of open-sourcing educational projects to target educators themselves to encourage their work with educational organizations. Using the example of a professional development calendar, created to support teacher-learning with civic and cultural institutions and organizations, we would like to showcase the benefits of open-sourcing an educational project within a community.

title: Scaling the leading & learning program for Participation at Mozilla

description:
This session will explore the ongoing challenge for community-based programs, non-profit organizations, and NGOs to make the best use of professional volunteers to achieve an impactful outcome. Participants in the session will identify the most scalable contributions to an open-source technology project (in particular) and co-construct a framework for engaging professional volunteers.
The perfect balance between a volunteer’s skills, availability and interests, and an organization’s needs is a tricky target to strike. When it is done successfully, there is a great mutual benefit to everyone involved. However, the most impactful contributions are those that provide a sustainable structure and enable an organization or project to scale.
Together with Mozilla designers experienced in limited-contribution, professional volunteer experiences and Mozilla educators experienced with community-based projects, participants will create an open, shared standard for structuring a professional volunteer engagements to maximize the success, impact, sustainability and scalability of a professional volunteer contribution.
pathways: Leading and Building Community Through Participation, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted
title: Open Practices for Scalable, Professional Contributions in Community-based Projects

We will explain the iceberg model from Otto Scharmer's Theory-U.
Following that there will be a discussion on how to apply his theory in our community work.
pathways: Leading and Building Community Through Participation

pathways: New Technologies for Participation -- Challenge, Participation Travel Stipend, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted

description: This session will gather folks interested in delivering organized learning experiences on the web.  We will brainstorm different tools that Mozillians can use to create a distributed learning experience. Given the number of respondents to the Pledge to Teach CTA who asked for professional development from MLN we will need to level up the instructional design of RCs, CCs, and metnors. We will focus on building classes that use open source tools and empower learners to develop their own content and learning pathways.

description:
Ever dreamt of hacking your mobile device to really suits your needs? This session will get you started on creating add-ons for Firefox OS to customise your device and get a truly tailored experience.
Bring your laptop and your Firefox OS device if you have one.
pathways: New Technologies for Participation -- Challenge, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted

description: My session will allow people to learn how to get started with open source contributions. Sometimes getting started can be daunting and this workshop hopes to lessen the learning curve. In a nutshell people would be walked through the steps on how to get started contributing to open source from the ground up. Raging from things as opportunities to translate, coding, close captioning, documentation and much more. Having a list of beginner friendly projects of Mozilla that are in need of contributors will be a great addition to the program, as then we can promote opportunities within Mozilla in addition to other open source projects.
title: Getting Started with Open Source Contributions

description:
Building a strong online and in person community:
Communities can exist online, in person and many times, both. When communities live successfully online and in person, they can really compliment one another. However, at times, they can feel very disconnected and like two separate communities. How can we bridge the gap between the online and in person, to ultimately create a more integrated community that builds momentum? How do you engage these two different types of communities in a way that gets them connecting with one another and breaking down that digital barrier?
pathways: Inclusive Communities, New Technologies for Participation -- Challenge, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted
title: Connecting online + in person communities

description: Cynefin Lego Game is a playful way to learn and experience four of the five domains of the Cynefin Framework (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cynefin), a leader’s framework for decision making which can be used to understand situations in organisations and in teamwork, and to decide how to approach them. By going through different exercises in which the problem to solve and the context will change, the attendees will learn the challenges behind each domain, and why we have to tackle them in very different ways. The game will let attendees experience the domains of Dave Snowden’s Cynefin framework, teamwork and the decision-making process in different scenarios. And have fun with Lego bricks of course :)
pathways: Leading and Building Community Through Participation, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted
title: Cultivating leadership by having fun: the Cynefin Lego Game

description: This is the kick-off session for the Pathway 'New Technologies for Participation - Challenge!' which asks you techie, story teller, maker, inventor to go out into Mozfest  - to learn,  hack and ultimately bring back new ideas for Participation at Mozilla.  If you can get away with it, bring the technology back with you as well.  This session will layout the challenge for Demo on Sunday!

description: Today's activist campaigns are innovative and connected, leveraging the web to build collective voice. Open source practice could amplify the power of contemporary activism by sharing resources and learning outcomes openly between movements. In this session we will use GitHub to codesign a framework for planning activist campaigns. It won't be too technical - if you can use a web browser you can learn to use GitHub during the session! We'll create a template to guide new movements with the benefit of your past experiences and together start to build a community-led repository for open source activism.
title: Campaign Hack - Codesigning a Framework for Activism

description: Privacy issues often result just due to how technology is architected! We address the latest issues in browser privacy and transparency mechanisms. Want to hear about the current browser developments and the possible privacy risks and walk away equipped with a privacy-sensitive mindset and concepts? Are we satisfied with how browsers work? Do we know what data are provided to Web sites by our browsers? We will discuss if - and how to possibly improve the user interfaces.
title: Putting users in charge: Introduction to the browser privacy UI

description: Participants will learn about and discuss issues around copyright reform in the EU, including current state of play, Mozilla's stance, foreseen obstacles that could come up in 2016, and what our coalition partners say.
title: CopyBetter: Copyright Reform in the EU

description:
My goals for this session would be the following:
1)	Raise awareness about the deadly consequences and harmful effects caused by the silent pandemic of cyberbullying and internet negativity.
2)	Educate participants on the alarming statistics on teen-age suicides, depression, anxiety and low self-esteem, all caused by cyberbullying.
3)	Discuss why most of the parental control or cyberbullying reporting solutions are not effective?
4)	Why does cyberbullying occur more in adolescents than adults?
5)	How does the ReThink software and movement tackle’s cyberbullying proactively?
6)	Why “ReThinking” before posting is the best strategy and how can it be integrated as part of our education systems and technology world.
7)	I strongly believe that, no one has to pay to be safe on the internet. I hope to have the participants carry this message
pathways: Don't Feed the Trolls, [DC] Accepted, [youthZone] Links with us
title: ReThink – An effective way to stop Cyber bullying

pathways: Don't Feed the Trolls, R-E-S-P-E-C-T, [DC] Accepted
title: Tools for Travelers on the Dark Side of the Internet

description: The internet has provided the opportunity for people all over the world to unify and spread a message. This session will be focused on brainstorming how to maximize the power of this connectedness for driving social and political change. We will review a few cases of the how communities on the internet have organized towards making a positive change, and then begin to bring together thoughts and knowledge on the most valuable techniques and online resources for empowering movements.
title: Serving Social Change: Leveraging the internet for the empowerment of social movements.

description:
Internet shutdowns represent a terrifying and real trend worldwide. Shutdowns and blocking often precede egregious human rights violations and impact our ability to seek, receive, and impart information. In 2015 alone, we've witnessed nearly a dozen shutdowns in a variety of contexts and situations, from the Pacific Rim to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In the first short section, I'll share key strategic lessons for activists about how to fight internet shutdowns, including: working with telcos to resist government orders, how to speak about shutdowns in human rights language, engaging the UN, pressuring government figures, capturing data about shutdowns, and storytelling for change. I'll also share key indicators that we have tracked over time.
The second, main part of the session will be wholly interactive and focus on a shutdown simulation that invites participants to respond to the shutdown.
title: How to Fight an Internet Shutdown

description:
* Security and Privacy being an important part of our online lives. This session will help attendees understand privacy and security on the internet better.
* I am taking a Firefox centric angle to showcase how Firefox puts the user first by guarding user data with privacy and  “do not tack” focussed approach.
* Participants will learn:
** How to take care of their privacy online
** Best practices to follow
** How firefox can help them do it - using Firefox Like a BOSS
** Various Privacy addons that can help user guard against unwanted tracking, ads and third-party cookies.
** Understanding cache, cookies and permissions on website.
** What is secure browsing (https)
** Cookies and trackers
*  This session is contemporary, essential and practical discussing Privacy & Security with peers, students, teachers and netizens.
title: Your Privacy on the Web (Using Firefox Browser and more)

description: Curt Schilling, Alanah Pearce and “Target’s Customer Service” are just a few people who’ve made news with creative ways to expose and shut down trolls on the Internet.  In this interactive session, iKeepSafe will share and request feedback on two projects designed to empower those who want to foster greater civility and respect online.  The first project, a partnership with Beyond Differences, is designed to address root causes of negative behavior by working with schools to promote inclusion and kindness.  The second project, working with the Tyler Clementi Center for Law & Policy at NY Law School, will provide education and resources to students, families, lawyers and judges as well as a first-of-its-kind law clinic dedicated to helping victims of online harassment.  During our session, we will explore ways to ensure these projects are inclusive and address real needs and will invite attendees to share their own ideas and projects.
title: Empowerment -- A Weapon Against Trolls

description: Privacy Lab is the place to get answer to all of your privacy questions.  Come meet our experts and explore privacy topics at your own pace! Booths will vary each hour and will include Ask Me Anything, Firefox Privacy Features, Digital Footprints, Privacy Tools from the Library Freedom Project, Router Hacking, DNT and the Future of Tracking, OffGridTheGame, and more.
facilitator_4: Ankit Gadgil, Diwanshi Pandey, Mayur Patel
title: Privacy Lab

description: Open _____ is a term we throw around all the time, but ultimately most open work happens through people talking to each other -- either from meeting on IRC, Twitter or at an in-person event, or a connection through an introduction. Open data, open mapping, open source, open web is at it’s core about working collectively to leverage technology to allow people to do, make, build, tell stories, protect, share, talk, meet, etc. At this session, we want to begin recognizing the human network we are building, develop some shared principles and think about how to be more intentional and supportive of efforts towards the open web community.
title: How Being Open Depends on Building Your Human Network

description:
A “Day of Action” is a common pattern in activism, join this session to learn about an open-source webapp that helps people & organizations coordinate large-scale collective actions.
The “Day of Action” app started in December 2014, on the heels police murdering Mike Brown in Ferguson, Missouri. High school students across the US began tweeting #HandsUpWalkOut--they were planning a national student walkout to protest police violence against people of color. This wasn’t organized by a formal organization, just high school kids on social media. That night I made the first version of “Day of Action” and put it on HandsUpWalkOut.com. Over the next two days,  student organizers used the app to coordinate 100+ walkouts & related actions. The tool provides a workflow for adding a local event and generates a map so others can find local actions. Thousands of people participated and the tool was used 100k times that weekend.
pathways: Building a Crowd, New Technologies for Participation -- Challenge, [DC] Accepted, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted
title: Day of Action: A web app to facilitate decentralized collective action

description:
Goal of the session is to make them aware of the following things:
* What is an information footprint?
* The fact that they are leaving digital footprints with everything they do (Intentionally/unintentionally).
* Factors that affect how exposed their information footprint is.
* How this footprint is affected by the aggregation and mining of data from different sources to judge a person's behavior and make their picture on that basis.
* Identify which of the ways they leave footprints they can control or minimize.
pathways: Backdoors + Cryptowars, Participation Travel Stipend, [DC] Accepted
title: Have you Measured your Information Footprint? "Its Larger Than You Think!!!"

description:
Discuss and learn the definitions of net neutrality, the most popular public outcries and perspectives, understand the experiences of different countries and especially draw parallels and/or distinctions between the developing country experience and the developed country experience.
Discover its’ impact on start-ups and web innovation.
Share methodology for identifying and engaging critical stakeholders for a nation with a view to finding balance and mapping a way forward that does not infringe on internet governance guidelines and rights.
Raise awareness on available resources and support groups in the internet access space.
pathways: Building a Crowd, Global Innovation Network, [DC] Accepted
title: Engaging Stakeholders on Net Neutrality & Impact on Youth Start-Ups /Innovation in Developing Countries

description:
Measurement Lab (M-Lab) has a number of tools for measuring network state and performance, and we're looking for help on digital campaign to promote our new Measure app. We’ll demo our “Measure App” and talk about ideas participants have on how their communities might use it. People will be able to install and use the app.
Also: In countries with growing Internet censorship policies, it is expected that heavier information controls will be imposed around political events such as elections. This workshop will look at current efforts by researchers and civil society actors to document and report on information controls, and to reduce disruption to online information and communications by proactively developing alternative modes of connectivity via circumvention technologies in response to various scenarios that could be induced by the authorities in Iran.
title: Open Tools for Network Measurement

description: People will know from a practical point of view what types of tecnocensura (tech censorship) exist, the sophisticated forms in which they operate and how we have developed methods in Mexico using open software tools and especially network communication techniques to deal with tecnocensura. Together, we'll learn how to detect bot attacks using Gephi, and hopefully start scoping new antibot software.
title: Tecnocensura: How to detect and face a bot attack

description: To begin thinking about online harassment as a technical problem as well as a social problem—one that can be both mitigated and exacerbated by technology and the technologists that create it. The framework discussed would empower creators, rather than leaving them to be helpless in the face of deep social ills that are reflected in online spaces. The session would summarize and build on top of my book, The Internet of Garbage, using the work of Randi Harper (GG Autoblocker) and Jacob Hoffman-Andrews (Blocktogether) as case studies.
pathways: Building Online Communities, Don't Feed the Trolls, New Technologies for Participation -- Challenge, [DC] Accepted, [PARTICIPATION] Accepted
title: Architecting Against Online Harassment

description:
Participants will learn that it is fun, easy and inexpensive to contribute to freedom of expression and access to information around the world by contributing to the Tor network.
Tor is open source software combined with a global network of developers and volunteers that provide online anonymity. It does this by routing a user’s Internet traffic through geographically-dispersed intermediate relaying computers all the while protecting traffic endpoint and content confidentiality.
During this session we will explain and then experience the various methods to contribute to Tor. This includes operating a Tor relay or bridge or simply using Tor for day-to-day web browsing. We will discuss the costs and requirements of the various options and show that people can meaningfully contribute for less than $10 per month while earning fun geek-garb.
Three concurrent paths within the session will allow participants to work at various technical depths and levels of investment.
title: Be Torrific!: Promoting Freedom of Expression with Tor

description: Participants will have the opportunity to pitch Internet policy issues and spaces in which Mozilla should be more involved to members of the Mozilla Policy Team and field experts.
title: Dino's Den

description: Task Forces are born out of recognition that like code, public policy has an impact on the shape and health of the open Web. Through task forces, we can empower people to create measurable changes in public policy to protect the Internet as a global public resource, open and accessible to all. In this session, we’ll use Mozilla's earlier net neutrality campaign and privacy teach-ins with the Indian community as a case study, and see how we can replicate this collaboration by bringing together Advocacy Task Forces in other regions. Come learn how you can participate.
pathways: Building a Crowd, What's your policy?, [DC] Accepted
title: Advocacy and Teach-In Task Forces

description: Off Grid is a video game about digital rights. It is an adventure, satire and stealth game about a mishap antihero. You play an everyman pencil pusher, who is oblivious to the city's prying and spying, corporate-sponsored government until a series of dark events unfold.
title: Off Grid - Exploring digital rights through entertainment

description: This session is a mini investigation of human rights abuses, drawing upon real life scenarios, that will enable participants to experience first hand what it takes to be a human rights CSI. It involves searching for content, thinking of chains of custody, documenting and verifying open source intelligence like satellite imagery, videos, images, text based reports, etc. and building an evidence wall.
title: Become a Human Rights CSI

description:
In this session we will remix the Feminist Principles of the Internet. We will come up with a version of these Principles aimed at people that love the Internet and believe in gender equality. And added fun challenge will be to make sure these Principles are tweetable (having 140 characters or less).
No laptop is needed for this session. All you need is eagerness to discuss the relation between women and the Internet and its related components (freedom of expression, violence, access, representation, economy and more).
These Principles were published by the APC (Association for Progressive Communications).
pathways: Don't Feed the Trolls, Global Village Athena Library, R-E-S-P-E-C-T, [DC] Accepted
title: A Feminist Internet in 140 Characters

description: We will explore the needs of transparency and accountability advocates for online tools and look at past efforts to create online tools for this sector.  Transparency and accountability work takes on many forms, from exposing corruption to pushing governments to releasing data about their activities.  Online tools have a particularly central role in helping to facilitate this work - but often suffer from usability issues and having sound business models behind them.  This session will focus on capturing lessons learned and developing tools that will succeed in supporting the work that is needed over the next few decades to assure accountability becomes a global cultural norm.
title: Tech Strategies for Grassroots Advocacy

description: We've seen incredible examples of open science and Citizen Science that have invited mass participation in addressing big scientific challenges: finding a cure for cancer, mapping planets or understanding our natural environment. We want to see if the characteristics of citizen science: mass participation, networked technology, open and accessible design, and the network effect can address big social challenges such as community health, youth unemployment or mental health. This session will work with the MozFest community to explore, hack and investigate the potential of citizen (social) science, building on our work in this area and working with a broader community to push forward this area of high potential. Participants will contribute to a new area of investigation, and one that can have a dramatic effect on the way we address big social issues today.
title: Citizen (social) Science

description: Attendees will learn about the current state of online tracking and user opt-out. They'll become familiar with Do Not Track history and EFF's new DNT policy as well as modern ad blocking tools. Attendees will have a sense of the online tracking ecosystem, and will have an opportunity to voice their concerns and suggestions for how to reform it. The session will also cover the technical details of how browsers are able to be tracked, what prevention tools do to circumvent this, and what browsers can do by default to aid users and tools. The hope is that attendees leave with a better understanding of what is going on and feel empowered to use the tools available to help reform the state of web tracking.
title: Ending Online Tracking - Do Not Track And Beyond

description: Participants will collaborate on a shared WebGL experience taking "living light" from a central server and creating individualized experiences. This project will illustrate the importance of opening up low-level APIs to the web, and how such technologies can empower transformative experiences.
title: Living Light with WebGL - A Collaborative Art Experience

pathways: Global Village Athena Library, Inclusive Communities
title: Diversity in the new economy
Creating adaptive storytelling content for the future of radio

description:
From documentation to storytelling, the Open Web offers both the content and tools required to make beautiful books. Groups of authors can be together in one room at Mozfest or spread across the globe.
There are now a variety of closed-cloud platforms which can be used to create books and ebooks. Booktype is the fully open source alternative, which can be installed on your own web server for complete independence.
This will be a hands-on session introducing authors to collaborative, browser-based book authoring, taking them from first draft to print PDF, EPUB and more.
title: How to make real books on the Open Web

description: Teach the use of story as a tool to build community. If a story is well told, the idea contained within it can take in every listener that hears it. If we see something that can change for the better then, irrespective of our position, we can be a leader - but we need the tools to inspire and motivate.
title: Story to Build Community

description: We are building a world-class engagement platform offering tools to push forward municipal broadband in communities across Canada. And at MozFest, we want to share this platform, and the importance of municipal broadband, with the world. Pioneering cities and towns have taken it upon themselves to close the digital divide by ensuring affordable, city-wide Internet access through municipal broadband networks. Our platform will build on the successes of these often disparate and isolated communities, and kickstart a new mass movement for municipal broadband initiatives that can be replicated anywhere. In the U.S. alone, over 100 communities have pledged to develop their own fibre, highlighting the role municipal networks can play in galvanizing the digital divide. Participants will receive a preview of our engagement platform to empower not just individuals, but entire communities, to organize in distributed, local groups, and address the digital deficits their cities and towns face.
title: Crowdsourcing the Next Gigabit Cities: An Engagement Platform for Municipal Broadband
Experiences of the Future Home

pathways: Global Village Athena Library, Inclusive Communities, [youthZone] Links with us
title: The web through the eyes of a dyslexic

pathways: Global Village Athena Library, Inclusive Communities
title: The reality of diversity: The working dead
The IoT Home Hub
Placeholder session for animal/environmental data & a/v content

pathways: Global Innovation Network, Global Village Recycling
title: Garbage Disposal Room

description:
A diverse group of artists/industry practitioners will come together to develop a web-based interactive lighting system.
A collaboration between Ravensbourne's Design & Coding and Product Design courses and Goldsmith's Creative Computing Department to develop a workshop on interactive lighting/gaming/web-based/physical computing, a hack session to show the tool-kit developed in order to invite students/industry to hack them. The project aims to develop 3D printed lights to install around the building which would be networked through the web.
title: Switched On(line) Lighting

description: What is an album on the web? Is this a place for research? Is this a place for memories? Is this a place for creative and visual making? Using the 'Albums' digital web platform from the Tate (www.tate.org.uk/art/albums), participants will be able to create their own artistic digital platforms. The Tate Albums feature is a way to pull together data, curate Tate artworks, research items and archive all user created content. The session will have an engaging learning curve around digital making and web literacy, allowing creative thinking and reflection. With both an individual and participatory group approach, the activity calls participants to start their own digital albums and share their personal interests, identities, art and more!
title: Tate Digital Learning - 'Albums, Sketches, Etc..!'

description: We will give participants free packs of Know Cards (worth $140) to learn how to invent the next generation products they want to see in their local John Lewis.  A lot of smart product ideas can emerge from knowing what the building blocks are and Know Cards does that in a visual and accessible way. From inputs, outputs, power and connectors participants will get a chance to learn how to use the cards and brainstorm product ideas that could be built.
title: The Invention Shop (with Know Cards)

description: People will learn how to use free 3D modeling software to create 3D printed objects. In the workshop you’ll create the right models that are suitable for 3D printing, and start with printing a small humanoid robot.
pathways: Global Village Garage, [youthZone] Links with us
title: Learn 3D modeling and print a robot.
Hip-hop, Hypertext & Hackerspace - Diversity Is Important, But Not For The Reasons You Think

description:
We’ll explore the opportunity, and urgency, for all of us to shape our shared future, through co-creation by designers, technologist and all who use the web.
It's not necessary for everyone to understand the details of, say climate change, to act now and do something about it.  There's a parallel with technology here as anyone can use the web, without knowing all the detail of how it works. User, and consumers, shape its future just as much as those who design build and design.  Fashion is like this too, consumers determine the future as much as designers.
Helen Storey and Michael Saunby will lead an exploration of how we can use the web to share visions of the future and calls to action, whether it be to ensure the freedom of the web or protection of the environment.
pathways: Global Village Garden, [youthZone] Links with us
title: Learning not to fear the future by sharing what we know

description:
The goal of the session is to teach participants how to educate, engage and empower individuals, local communities & organizations to make impact through a collaborative platform.
Help create/ identify various ways to support hackers, makers, startups and creative people. Promote experiential learning, co-creation and collaboration through the interests of people.
The aim is to bring in various communities together to work on the things they like, connect, share, teach and build.
The activity will focus on benefits of embracing the Open Practices. Understanding a few case studies and hands-on workshop to build the structure for various scenarios.
The participants will learn how research, knowledge exchange, learning and mentoring with each other can be driven.
A part of the session will be focused around discussing what a open and inclusive space is to them.
Learn how to make these spaces sustainable so they can continue make impact in long run.
title: Collaborative Community Spaces

description:
In the ‘Modular frequencies’ workshop we’ll create a spacial audio installation! The HearUsHere app (location based audio) combined with iBeacons allows us to create a new sonic experience. Every iBeacon is a frequency that carriers a sound, when you get closer to one of these frequencies the audio will automatically fade in and cross fade with others. Using the speakers of our phones, we’ll create a collective audio experience. This results in unique and constantly changing soundscape created by the visitors and their navigation in the space.
Within the workshop you won’t only experience these modular frequencies. You’ll learn about frequencies, location based audio and you’ll hack the beacons to create your own ‘pirate radio’! (No coding skills required).
title: Modular frequencies - HearUsHere soundlab
Eye contact experiments
Connecting old games with the BBC Micro:Bit

description: The vast technology penetration in emerging countries (such as Indonesia) led to a lot of people become online. The problem arises when they don't care or aware about online privacy which can lead to criminal activities such as fraud, scam, kidnapping, etc. There are a lot of tools that can enhance privacy in online world. But the main problem is online behavior. This session will discuss how to make people change their online behavior.
title: Online (Behavior) Privacy Awareness

description:
Mental health is an ignored corner of the tech world for far too many of us. We know it's an essential part of our personal and working lives, yet so little attention is paid to it due to stigma or lack of awareness. We all have some level of personal experience with it, whether we realise it or not.
This session will be addressing the changing place that mental health occupies in tech. We will discuss the past and current state of mental health and emotional wellness, factors that exist that affect it, and ways that we can change views and create a more supportive space for the growth of mental health in our community. Personal, cultural, political, economic and technological influences will be examined and combined in discussion and exercises to facilitate ideas about how to hack mental health in tech.
title: Hacking Mental Health: Changing Views in Tech

description: Rapidly-changing digital policies across the world are contributing to the decline of the democratizing power of the hyperlink and its ability to create the interconnected information space that was imagined by Tim Berners-Lee. One such example is the ancillary copyright law implemented in Spain in 2014–a proposal that was rejected EuroParl for EU-wide implementation, but threatens to return with the drafting of updates to the Copyright Directive. To fight back against these policies, an international network of over 90 digital rights organizations, businesses, journalists and Internet users from 30 countries have convened under the banner of “SaveTheLink” to catalogue and push back against sustained threats to the link. In this session, participants will learn about new policies that make it easier for governments and corporations to demand and implement link censorship, and will help identify threats and brainstorm tactics/solutions to address these threats to the link in an interactive workshop.
pathways: Global Village Athena Library, What's your policy?
title: Is the hyperlink dead?

pathways: Global Village Recycling, [Pathway] Storytellers & coders united: together we can change the world!
title: Inspiration time: explore recent projects that will change the way you understand the world

description:
Discussion about the happiness and how it relates to the  digital era.
Outcomes - every participant to fell inspired and empowered to create positive interactions in their work and life.
Awareness of the role of the individual, the media and technological impact on individual and community psychology.
Ideas for how to create trust and positivity in their communities.
title: Happiness in the Digital Era

description: Our session will introduce participants to the process of AI design in a human-centric and empathetic way. Participants will have the opportunity to design the system rules for their own AI and will the co-create some potential societal impact scenarios that these designed AIs will have on relationships we have with each other, technology and the world at large.
title: How will artificial intelligence change our interactions with each other?

description: The Local Web will explore options for local communication when the wider internet is not available. This will include self-hosting, community and mesh networks, device-to-device communication, delay tolerant networking, service discovery, and more. This workshop will explore possibilities for using the web and other internet technologies on a local, rather than global, scale.
title: The Local Web

description:
A picture says a thousand words - and it’s never been easier to create images that can have real impact.
If you’d asked me a couple of years ago - “Can you draw?” I’d have said “Not really - I’m a programmer”. However, creating visual thoughts is now central to everything I do.
This session will aim to illustrate how a visual thought can be captured, created and shared and if this wasn’t just a lowly text form, I’d put a few examples in to show what I mean.
Unfortunately, visual thoughts are limited by your ability to think…
title: Capturing a visual thought

description:
Participants will design 'services' to improve crowdsourced and collaborative coverage of festivals.
This could be anything from a 'Mozilla Webmaker' for live content aggregation to Internet of Things-based services or even something entirely paper-based that doesn't use any electronic/computer tech.
We are especially interested in creating services that connect people together, both on-site and off-site.
title: Supporting collaborative festival coverage
20 new ways of sharing: learning co-creation through community engagements
Slow ethnography as a tool for co-creation

description: This is where you can write your session description. Ideally it will be 50 words or less (if longer, we'll automatically truncate it) and without any fancy formatting.
